A couple of previous answers have offered good examples of groups who benefit from poverty per se – especially Matt Chanoff ‘s example of those who specialize in lending to poor people with poor credit histories, as well as the bureaucrats mentioned by Ken Adney, along with other members of the “poverty-industrial complex”—high-paid execs of poverty-focused NGOs. But the broader implication of the question and its details—that the persistence of poverty proves that someone must be benefiting from keeping the poor poor – is incorrect. The reality is a bit more subtle. In essentially all developing countries, where the vast majority of poor people live, the economy is burdened by economic distortions whose intended effect is to restrict competition with existing dominant firms, whose owners constitute a powerful set of interest groups lobbying against economic reform. To cite but one example among many, the trucking industry in many countries in Sub-Saharan Africa is monopolized by politically powerful interests, e.g. in South Sudan by the former president’s wife. These monopolies drive up prices, worsen service, and limit pressure for improved productivity. Multiplied manifold in each poor country, the net result are economies growing more slowly and operating less productively than they would otherwise in a more competitive environment. The end result is slow growth in the modern economy, leaving most of the labor force stuck in poverty in traditional agriculture and the urban informal sector. In short, no one deliberately sets out to keep poor people poor; rather, the poor simply suffer the collateral damage created by the efforts of interest groups to restrict competition that would threaten their own vested interests.
